channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for SC
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration, for SC

item.title: Report E-2023090248
item.description:
Report E-2023090248

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-14T03:11:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-06
  • City: Easley
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LANDSTAR EXPRESS AMERICA, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 06, 2023, at 1135 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Landstar personnel in Easley, South Carolina regarding the release of approximately (1) gallon of ORGANIC PEROXIDE TYPE C, LIQUID, TEMPERATURE CONTROLLED (UN3113, 5.2) from (1) 5-gallon Jerrican. Contractors were dispatched to the site to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors were informed by facility personnel that the release was due to a load shift during transit and contained to the trailer floor. No drains or waterways were impacted by the release. Facility personnel cleaned and containerized the release prior to contractorsâ€™ arrival and will be responsible for managing the waste.

item.title: Report X-2023081209
item.description:
Report X-2023081209

  • City: LADSON

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package located completely wet/destroyed, liquid contents having escaped. Package was isolated from sortation to ensure safety. DescribePack: Loose cap on 1 jug allowed liquid contents to escape container. DurationRel: 2 and MitigateEffect: Package was separated from sortation and placed in hazardous materials tub to prevent further spillage.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: We noticed dripping coming from the package and the action taken once discovered was to take the package and set it aside to be inspected for the cause & resolution. DescribePack: On the bottom neck of the package, we noticed a pin hole leak. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Remove the leaking item and placing it into a black tote.

item.title: Report I-2023080023
item.description:
Report I-2023080023

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-16T00:32:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-06-14
  • City: INMAN
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: HILCO TRANSPORT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Hilco Transport Company picked up a shipment of liquid asphalt at the Associated Asphalt terminal in Inman, SC. While travelling on US Hwy 176, a boil-over of the material occurred, resulting in the release of an estimated 75 gallons of liquid asphalt to the paved road surface. The material did not impact soil and/or surface water systems or surface water bodies. The liquid asphalt was stabilized using sand, then allowed to cool. After cooling, the asphalt material was recovered and transported for recycling.

item.title: Report I-2023070044
item.description:
Report I-2023070044

Identified by scraper @ 2023-09-16T00:32:33+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-05-15
  • City: LAURENS
  • State: SC
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: FREEHOLD CARTAGE INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver and technician were transferring drum from pallet onto trailer floor when It suddenly cracked, causing contents of drum to spill out. The liquid spilled onto concrete and trace amounts impacted storm drain. Generator responded immediately to mitigate spill and potential environmental cleanup. Pigs were placed around storm drain which prevented most of the liquid from entering storm drain which helped isolate further cleanup and liquid run off. Acid absorbent material and lime were used to soak up remaining liquid. The PPE and contents of cleanup were placed ln over pack drum and transported to TSDF as required. After Inspection grounds it was determined no liquid was visibility detected in outfall nor did It Impact round soil. Under the advisement from South Carolina Department of Health and Enviromental (SCDHEC) llme was dispensed into storm drain as added precaution. In addition, quarterly storm-water was recommended to assure no further contamination occurred.
